review.title: Improving the quality of Gujarati-Hindi Machine Translation through part-of-speech tagging and stemmer-assisted transliteration
review.abstract: Machine Translation for Indian languages is an emerging research area. Transliteration is one such module that we design while designing a translation system. Transliteration means mapping of source language text into the target language. Simple mapping decreases the efficiency of overall translation system. We propose the use of stemming and part-of-speech tagging for transliteration. The effectiveness of translation can be improved if we use part-of-speech tagging and stemming assisted transliteration.We have shown that much of the content in Gujarati gets transliterated while being processed for translation to Hindi language.

metadata.title: IMPROVING THE QUALITY OF GUJARATI-HINDI MACHINE TRANSLATION THROUGH PART-OF-

sections.text: DOI: 10.5121 / ijnlc.2013.2305 49Machine Translation for Indian Languages is an emerging field of research. Transliteration is one such module that we design when designing a translation system. Transliteration means mapping the source text into the target language. Simple mapping reduces the efficiency of the entire translation system. We suggest the use of stemming and part-of-speech tagging for translation. The effectiveness of translation can be improved when we use part-of-speech tagging and stemming-supported transliteration. We have shown that much of the content in Gujarati is translated into the Hindi language during translation. KEYWORDSStemming, Transliteration, Part-of-Speech-Tagging

sections.heading: 1. INTRODUCTION
sections.text: While designing a translation model, transliteration proves to be an effective tool for words that are multilingual or that are not present in the training corpus. In a highly flexible Indian language such as Gujarati, naive transliteration, i.e. direct transliteration without rules or restrictions, proves to be not very effective. The main reason for this is that suffixes are attached to the root words as they form a sentence. We suggest the use of stemming and POS tagging (i.e. part-of-speech tagging) for the transliteration process. Stemming refers to the removal of suffixes from the root word. Root is actually the keyword to which suffixes are added. For example, in (striiomaNthii) the root and suffix are described.

sections.heading: 2. LITERATURE REVIEW
sections.text: Two other algorithms deriving from the system were proposed by Hafer and Weiss [2] and Paice [3]. Martin Porter [4] proposed a suffix stripping algorithm in 1980, which is still considered the standard, based on an algorithm derived from purely rules-based algorithms. A further approach to descent was proposed by Frakes and Baeza-Yates [5], who proposed the use of term indexes and its root word in a tabular retrospective. As processing capacities improved, there was a paradigm shift from purely rules-based techniques to statistical / machine learning approaches. Goldsmith [6] proposed an unsupervised approach to the morphological variants of European languages. Snover and Brent [8] proposed a Bayesian model for descent of English and French languages. Freitag [9] proposed an algorithm for clustering words.

sections.heading: 3. PROPOSED WORK
sections.text: There are three genders in Gujarati - Feminine, Masculine and Neutral. Suffixes are added to the stems that give the different morphological variants of the same root word. We propose the use of stemming and POS tagging for the purpose of transliteration. Figure 1 shows our system.Figure 1. Transliteration is tagged with Stemming and Part-of-Speech taggingMany ambiguities are observed while designing a translation model from Gujarati Hindi. Onesuch ambiguity is the distinction of the suffix in various cases. Suppose we have this origin (Raam ne mujhe riport dii.) (Meaning: Ram gave me the report.) | (Maaraa ghare ek bilaadichhe.)

sections.heading: 4. EVALUATION AND RESULTS
sections.text: We tested our system on a total of 500 sentences. The results observed are as follows: 54.48% of the Gujarati words are translated and transliterated in the same way, and the efficiency of our transliteration scheme is 93.09% (about 90%).

sections.heading: 5. CONCLUSION AND FUTURE WORK
sections.text: We took a hybrid approach - a mixture of rules-based and corpus-based approaches, using POS-marked corpus and tribal rules to support the transliteration process. We achieved an overall efficiency of the transliteration program of 93.09%, making it a promising approach. It was observed that 54.48% of the words from Gujarati have the same translation and translation. Such a scheme not only reduces the length of the corpus for the translation model, but also helps to resolve ambiguities. It can also be used for other morphologically rich Indian languages. As an immediate extension of this work, we plan to incorporate more machine learning approaches and focus on every single aspect of the scheme so that more accuracy can be achieved in the translation process.

referenceMentions.context: Stemming was actually introduced by Lovins [1] who in 1968 proposed the use of it in Natural Language Processing applications.
Two more stemming algorithms were proposed by Hafer and Weiss [2] and Paice [3].
Two more stemming algorithms were proposed by Hafer and Weiss [2] and Paice [3].
Martin Porter [4] in 1980 suggested a suffix stripping algorithm which is still considered to be a standard stemming algorithm.
Another approach to stemming was proposed by Frakes and Baeza- Yates [5] who proposed the use of term indexes and its root word in a table lookup.
Goldsmith [6][7] proposed an unsupervised approach to model morphological variants of European languages.
Goldsmith [6][7] proposed an unsupervised approach to model morphological variants of European languages.
Snover and Brent [8] proposed a Bayesian model for stemming of English and French languages.
Freitag [9] proposed an algorithm for clustering of words using cooccurrence information.
[10] used 27 rules to implement a stemmer for Hindi.
Ramanathan and Rao [11] used the same approach, but used some more rules for stemming.
Dasgupta and Ng [12] proposed an unsupervised morphological stemmer for Bengali.
[13] proposed a cluster based approach based on string distance measures which required no linguistic knowledge.
Pandey and Siddiqui [14] proposed an unsupervised approach to stemming for Hindi, which was mostly based on the work of Goldsmith.
Considering the research work for part-of-speech tagging, Church [15] proposed n-gram model for tagging, which was then extended as HMM by Cutting et al.
Brill [17] proposed a tagger based on transformation-based learning.
Ratnaparkhi [18] proposed Maximum Entropy algorithm.
[19] have proposed a morphology-based disambiguation for Hindi POS tagging.
[20] have proposed Feature Rich POS Tagger for Hindi.
Patel and Gali [21] have proposed a tagging scheme for Gujarati using Conditional Random Fields.
Arulmozhi and Sobha [23] have developed a hybrid POS-Tagger for relatively free word order language.
[24] and Sediqqui et al.
[25] have done significant research in the area of POS-Tagging.
Antony and Soman [26] used kernel-based approach for Kannada POS-Tagging.
Moving towards the work for transliteration, Kirschenbaum and Wintner [27] have proposed a lightly supervised transliteration scheme.
[28] used a combination of neural net and expert systems for transliteration.
[29] at LTRC, IIIT-H proposed a language-independent schema using character aligned models.
[30] followed a hybrid approach for Urdu-Hindi transliteration.
Joshi and Mathur [31] proposed the use of phonetic mapping based English-Hindi transliteration system which created a mapping table and a set of rules for transliteration of text.
